terms.definition: Printed Circuit Board - a flat board that mechanically supports and electrically connects electronic components using conductive tracks, pads and other features etched from copper sheets
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a service provider and accessed via the internet
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to revert to previous versions and compare modifications
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A pre-designed document format or structure that can be reused and customized for creating consistent documentation across projects
A detailed document that outlines the testing approach, objectives, resources, schedule, and procedures for evaluating a product or system
The ability to track and link requirements, changes, and test results throughout the development lifecycle to ensure accountability and compliance
The capability for multiple users to see changes to documents or data immediately as they occur, without manual refresh or synchronization
A software service that runs on remote servers accessible via the internet, rather than being installed locally on individual computers
The process of ensuring that products, processes, or documentation meet specific regulatory standards, industry requirements, or legal obligations
The systematic process of identifying, analyzing, and fixing defects or problems in electronic systems or software
The process of establishing uniform formats, procedures, or criteria to ensure consistency across documentation and processes
The process of connecting different software tools or systems to work together seamlessly and share data automatically
A defined sequence of steps or processes that automate and streamline the completion of tasks or document creation
A digital workspace that enables multiple users to work together on documents or projects simultaneously, sharing resources and communicating in real-time
